title: CVPR_1993_10_abs

sentences.text: A model-based approach to on-line cursive handwriting analysis and recognition is presented and evaluated .
In this model , on-line handwriting is considered as a modulation of a simple cycloidal pen motion , described by two coupled oscillations with a constant linear drift along the line of the writing .
By slow modulations of the amplitudes and phase lags of the two oscillators , a general pen trajectory can be efficiently encoded .
These parameters are then quantized into a small number of values without altering the writing intelligibility .
A general procedure for the estimation and quantization of these cycloidal motion parameters for arbitrary handwriting is presented .
The result is a discrete motor control representation of the continuous pen motion , via the quantized levels of the model parameters .
This motor control representation enables successful word spotting and matching of cursive scripts .
Our experiments clearly indicate the potential of this dynamic representation for complete cursive handwriting recognition .

summary: A model-based approach to on-line cursive handwriting analysis and recognition is presented and evaluated . In this model , on-line handwriting is considered as a modulation of a simple cycloidal pen motion , described by two coupled oscillations with a constant linear drift along the line of the writing . By slow modulations of the amplitudes and phase lags of the two oscillators , a general pen trajectory can be efficiently encoded . These parameters are then quantized into a small number of values without altering the writing intelligibility . A general procedure for the estimation and quantization of these cycloidal motion parameters for arbitrary handwriting is presented . The result is a discrete motor control representation of the continuous pen motion , via the quantized levels of the model parameters . This motor control representation enables successful word spotting and matching of cursive scripts . Our experiments clearly indicate the potential of this dynamic representation for complete cursive handwriting recognition .

Predicate-presented.label: presented
Predicate-presented.description: The predicate 'presented' indicates that the subject has shown or introduced the object to an audience, often implying a formal or official presentation. It suggests a sense of public disclosure or sharing, where the subject brings attention to the object's significance, value, or importance.

Predicate-evaluated.label: evaluated
Predicate-evaluated.description: The predicate 'evaluated' indicates that the subject has been assessed or judged against a standard or criteria, resulting in an evaluation of the object. It implies a process of examination, analysis, and assessment to determine the quality, accuracy, or effectiveness of the object.

Predicate-is_considered_as_a_modulation_.label: is considered as a modulation of
Predicate-is_considered_as_a_modulation_.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (e.g., on-line handwriting) is viewed or interpreted as an instance or manifestation of a specific modulating force, process, or pattern (e.g., cycloidal pen motion). In other words, it suggests that the subject's characteristics, behavior, or properties are shaped by and can be understood in terms of the object (modulation), which serves as a underlying influence or driving mechanism.

Predicate-described_by.label: described by
Predicate-described_by.description: The predicate 'described by' indicates that the subject (a phenomenon or process) can be understood, characterized, or explained in terms of the object (a concept, theory, model, or description). It suggests a relationship where the subject's nature, behavior, or underlying mechanisms are captured or represented by the object.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' indicates an identification or equivalence relationship between its subject and object. It suggests that the subject and object share a common characteristic, property, or nature, implying a state of being or existence.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates that the subject has the capacity to facilitate or make possible the occurrence or existence of the object. It implies a causal relationship where the subject's presence, state, or action allows for or permits the object to happen, exist, or be achieved.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates that the subject employs or exploits the object in some way, often implying a purposeful or intentional action. It suggests a relationship of utilization, where the subject derives benefit from or makes use of the object's properties, characteristics, or resources.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject provides or offers the object, often in a formal or official manner. It implies a sense of introduction, exposition, or display, where the subject is responsible for making the object known to others.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is a specific instance or subclass of the object concept. It establishes a hierarchical relationship between the two, where the subject is more narrow and detailed than the object.
